metadata.title: Analysis of emerging contaminants and nanomaterials in plant materials following uptake from soils

Analysis of emerging contaminants and nanomaterials in plant materials following uptake from soils
Yolanda Pic o a, *, Ahmed Alfarham b, Dami a Barcel o b, c
a Environmental and Food Safety Research Group (SAMA-UV), Desertification Research Centre CIDE (CSIC-UV-GV), Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Valencia, Av. Vicent Andr es Estell es s/n, Burjassot, 46100 Valencia, Spain b Department of Botany and Microbiology, College of Science, King Saud University, P.O. Box 2455, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia c IDAEA-CSIC, Jordi Girona 18-26, 08034 Barcelona, Spain
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Available online 24 July 2017
Keywords: Analytical methods Emerging contaminants Engineering nanomaterials Extraction Separation Determination Detection of nanoforms Plant uptake
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: yolanda.pico@uv.es (Y. Pic o).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.trac.2017.07.016 0165-9936/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
The reuse of treated wastewater or wastewater-impacted river water is growing, particularly in arid areas, due to the climate change. As well, the disposal of sludges, biosolids or biochar as soil amendments to improve agricultural output is widely implemented in the EU. These practices can be a source of emerging contaminants and engineering nanomaterials (ENMs) to the environment and condition their incorporation to food chain that could affect human beings. This review covers current analytical techniques, instruments and methodologies used to determine emerging contaminants and ENMs from irrigation water and/or soil amendments in plants. Trends regarding sample treatment, separation and detection approaches are addressed. Special emphasis is placed on in-situ characterization of ENMs (e.g. particle size distribution, shape, aggregation state, etc.). We also discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the analytical methods and techniques for determining emerging contaminants and fully ENMs characterization, and cover promising future prospects.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Sewage sludge is an inevitable by-product of wastewater treatment processes. Its application in agricultural land is of particular importance. The sewage sludge Directive 86/278/EEC [1], which requires an update, was adopted over 20 years ago to promote the application of sewage sludge in agriculture and regulate its use, so as to prevent harmful effects on the environment and humans. Treatedwastewater or wastewater-impacted riverwater is reused in arid regions, i.e., Mediterranean countries, California, Australia, Saudi Arabia, etc. for agriculture and aquifer recharge [2e4]. Recently, the European Union [5] established the quality requirements of this treated water and lists the risks derived from its use for agricultural soils, (i.e. salinization, etc,). Both, sewage sludge and water, contain emerging contaminants [human and veterinary pharmaceuticals, personal care products (PCPs), polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs), perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) and pesticides) as well as engineering nanomaterials (ENMs) at low levels. However, there is still a lack of knowledge on
their accumulation in soil and the subsequent uptake by plants that possess some inherent risks when applied to agricultural crops for food production [4,6e17]. Few reviews have been published on plant uptake of pharmaceuticals, PCPs and ENMs [2,3,12,13,18,19]. The biggest challenges are: (i) the wide range of contaminants and materials that differ in polarity, characteristics and size [from pharmaceuticals to PBDEs and from gold nanoparticles (Au-NPs) to multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)]; (ii) their low concentrations in plant tissues [usually in the ng g 1 dry weight (d.w.) range], and (iii) the matrix complexity which contains pigments, waxes, fats, cellulose, lignin, etc.
However, to date only two review papers reported the analytical methodology for contaminants of emerging concern [19] and pharmaceuticals [2] in plant materials. Both of them, pointed out the lack of multiresidue methods for determining emerging contaminants and their intermediate degradation products in crops at trace levels as well as the need to identify metabolites formed in these biological systems, and its dependence onmass spectrometry advances to improve identification. Currently, studies on the interaction of ENMs with plant tissues focus on the accumulation and phytotoxicity as a prelude to their actual quantification that is not yet properly resolved from the analytical point of view [12,13].
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189174
To our knowledge, only one review by Castillo-Michel et al. [20] focused on visualizing ENMs in plants by synchrotron based micro- and nano-X-ray fluorescence mapping and X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Some more reports cover the analytical techniques for the detection and measurement of ENMs in environmental materials [21e24]. Difficulties arise from sample preparation, lack of standard protocols, particle concentration below the limits of detection (LODs) and complex interaction of ENMswith other plant components. Despite the above gaps of knowledge and constraints, different techniques have been successfully used to detect and characterize ENMs in plants.
In this review, we provide a critical assessment of the various state-of-the-art analytical methodologies employed for the determination of emerging contaminants and ENMs in plant uptake studies. The relevant original scientific works published since 2012 show the advances made to analyse both, emerging contaminants and ENMs in plant materials and underline the still existing gaps within the subject. We highlight the challenges on sampling, characterization and analytical determination. Finally, an outlook towards the near future in terms of development with respect to equipment and methodologies to determine emerging contaminants and ENMs is presented.

sections.heading: 2. Emerging contaminants
sections.text:
There is vast range of emerging contaminants already determined in plants to establish their uptake and accumulation. These comprise pharmaceuticals and PCPs, PFASs, halogenated-flame retardants, pesticides, etc. Few studies deal with the behaviour of organic pollutants in crops after irrigation with treated wastewater or application of sewage sludge, biochar or biosolids to agricultural land [25e28]. However, there are a number of works describing the uptake of emerging contaminants by plants in laboratory or field controlled experiments inwhich the amount of contaminant added to irrigation water [29], nutrient solution [30], soil [30e32], biosolid amended soil [30] or directly from undiluted biosolids is known and relatively high. An important conclusion of all these studies that deserves to bementioned here is that concentrations of these compounds in plant are low (at ng g 1 level). However, these studies also pointed out the importance to carry out experiments using realistic concentrations of emerging contaminants and exposure pathways to avoid overestimation of the potential environmental risks of these contaminants. Consequently, the major pressure is on the accuracy, sensitivity, effectiveness and reliability of the analytical methodology and on requirements to meet these needs.
Overall, the reported methodologies (Table 1) comprise analyte extraction of the plant sample, subsequent purification of the extract, and final analysis by either gas or liquid chromatography (GC or LC) coupled mostly to mass spectrometry (MS) or tandem MS (MS2) detection. Fig. 1 schematizes the workflow followed to carry out most of these analyses.

sections.heading: 2.1. Extraction procedures
sections.text:
The most common method to extract emerging contaminants from plant materials is solid liquid extraction (SLE). Compounds of a polar or ionic nature (PFASs, pharmaceuticals, PCPs and some pesticides) are extracted with polar organic solvents [methanol, acetonitrile, acetone, methyl ter-butyl ether (MTBE), etc. or their mixtures with water] [32]. Those non-polar (PBDEs, UV filters, and a few pesticides) are isolated by non-polar/non-water miscible solvents, such as ethyl acetate, hexane or dichloromethane. In the studies summarized in Table 1, exhaustive extractions of plant materials not achievable just by mechanical shaking but by Soxhlet
extraction [25,26,45,48], pressurized liquid extraction (PLE), microwave assisted extraction (MAE) [4,30,36,38,39,41,47] and ultrasound-assisted extraction (USE) [51,52] are reported. These techniques, with the exception of Soxhlet have advantages as higher efficiency, shorter analysis time, analytes preservation, userfriendly design and low consumption of organic solvents. Furthermore, PLE includes its less polluting version d pressurized hot water extraction (PHWE) d [36,38] for polar analytes such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories and antibiotics. A PHWE extract is an aqueous solution easily cleaned up and concentrated by solid phase extraction (SPE). Another exploited PLE option is the selective incell clean-up that involves filling of the stainless-steel cell with multilayers of sorbents before introducing the sample, and integrates extraction and clean-up in a single step [4,39]. Matrix solid phase dispersion (MSPD) as miniaturized extraction has been sporadically applied for PFASs and pharmaceuticals [37,46] probably because the amount of sample that can be treated is low, which limits the sensitivity of the method.
SPE is the best technique for the fractionation/purification step. Polymeric sorbents, mainly the hydrophilic-lipophilic balance (HLB) (N-vinylpyrrolidone-divinylbenzene) eluted with methanol, are the preferred system to clean-up pharmaceuticals and PCPs [9,10,26,28,31,32,35,38,41e43]. SPE offers the advantages of being rapid, economical, simple to use and its automatization increases throughput with excellent results [34]. Alternatively, mixed-mode sorbents consisting of HLB and a strong cationic exchanger [29], dispersive SPE (DSPE) with activated carbon [40] and hollow fibre liquideliquid micro-extraction (HF-LLME) [36] could increase the selectivity while reducing matrix interferences. Emerging persistent organohalogenated contaminants are mostly cleaned up by either multi-layered columns with Florisil, alumina, silica or/and their acidic versions [25,40,45,47,48,50], or carbon sorbents (column, SPE, DSPE) [25,46,49,54]. Liquideliquid partitioning (LLE) of aqueous acetone extracts and dichloromethane [53] or water and MTBE after ion pairing [44] are still sporadically used. On the other hand, hexane (or other apolar solvents) can remove pigments or fats from plant extracts [34]. Other specific steps involved EDTA to avoid metal complexes [27,28], activated copper granules to remove elemental sulfur [45,48] or sulfuric acid wash to extract non-oxidizing compounds [25].
However, there is no consensus regarding the efficiency of different solvents and extraction methods for a specific type of contaminants and advantages and disadvantages according to particular plant and/or analyte characteristic are not clearly established. In other words, the analyst's choice is often a best guess. The pioneering study of Montemurro et al. [34] throws some light by comparing four extraction techniques (SLE, PLE, USE and QuEChERS) to extract simultaneously thirteen pharmaceuticals in lettuce leaves. For each technique, six different extraction solvent mixtures consisting of acetonitrile/methanol, MTBE/methanol, hexane/acetone, MTBE/acetonitrile, ethyl acetate/methanol, and 0.5% formic acid in acetonitrile/methanol were tested. The first extraction mixture was the best option to extract pharmaceuticals from lettuce leaves by any of the techniques. Best technique was USE since SLE provided high variability (RSDs > 20%), QuEChERS gave recoveries >50% for only half of the studied compounds and PLE did not recover any analytes. Studies like this are the embryo to expand the scope of these methods and establish standard protocols.

etc.) are determined by gas chromatography (GC) whereas polar, ionic and thermollabile emerging contaminants (pharmaceuticals and PCPs, PFASs and few pesticides) are almost invariably analysed by liquid chromatography (LC) (Table 1).
2.2.1. Liquid chromatography As can be observed in Table 1, either, LC or ultra-high performance liquid chromatography (UHPLC) applying columns with particle size < 1.7 mm (better separation in shorter chromatographic runs) are almost always carried out in the reversed-phase mode, mainly using C18 stationary phases. Generally, for the reversed-phase separation of emerging contaminants acidified water (with small amounts of formic acid or acetic acid) and methanol or acetonitrile as organic solvents (in some cases also acidified with formic acid or acetic acid) are used as mobile phases.
LC detectors applied are UV, fluorescence and different mass spectrometers. UV or diode array [37,40,51] is not selective because many compounds absorb at the low UV-wavelengths used (200e325 nm depending on the target analytes). Sensitivity achieved in plant materials is in the mg g 1 range. Consequently, high initial concentrations of the target analytes were needed in order to obtain concentration levels in the plants above the LODs. Levels of analytes to establish the uptakewere about 10 times higher than levels found in surface waters or sludges. Fluorescence detection is selective as demonstrated for ibuprofen and its metabolites (hydroxyibuprofen and dihydroxyibuprofen) [10]. LODs were <10 ng g 1 d.w. Then, they can be applied to investigate the removal from and the metabolism in plants exposed to environmental relevant concentrations (0.02 mg L 1 in the irrigation water). However, its application is limited to the few emerging contaminants that are fluorescent.
Previous reviews on the determination of emerging contaminants in plants highlight howmass spectrometry detectorsmarked a turning point in the field because they are more sensitive, universal and selective attaining determination at real low environmental concentrations for many compounds [2,19]. Single quadrupole mass analyzers have been used to determine ketoprofen, naproxen, diclofenac and ibuprofen in plant that grow in soil treated with sludges [36]. The LODs are at ng g 1 level (which is about 1000 times lower than those obtained for UV detection and one order of magnitude lower than those obtained by fluorescence). Although diclofenac and ibuprofen were determined in the sludge at 22 and 217 ng g 1 d.w., respectively, they were not detected in treated plants.
LCeMS/MS or UHPLCeMS/MSmethods using triple quadrupole (QqQ) mass analyzers are most frequently used to determine emerging contaminants in plant tissues because of their high sensitivity and selectivity. Analysis is undertaken using electrospray ionization (ESI) in positive or negative ionization modes depending on the compound and in the multiple selected reaction monitoring (MRM) acquisition mode (Table 1). Sensitivity typically ranges from hundreds of pg to few ng g 1 being 10 times or even more sensitive than LCeMS. Identification of the analytes was carried out by means of retention times and MRM ion transitions to authentic reference standards. Commonly, two selected reaction monitoring (SRM) transitions for compounds are selected to confirm analyte identity, but some emerging contaminants as ibuprofen (commonly ionized in negative mode) provided only one SRM due to poor fragmentation. The quadrupole linear ion trap (QTRAP) e that combines quadrupoles and a linear ion trap e is also used in some studies but only in the MRMworking mode as a very sensitive QqQ able to detect tens of pg g 1 (about 10 times more sensitive than QqQ) [29,34,38]. Using this approach, compounds with carboxylic acid groups, such as diclofenac, ibuprofen, valsartan, and valsartan acid were amenable to both positive and
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189178
negative ESI. Although the latter provided higher signal intensity, ibuprofen provided two SRM transitions in positive ESI, which is important to confirm identity. A representative total ion chromatogram (TIC) and extracted ion chromatograms (XIC) of the target analytes obtained after on-line SPEeLCeESI(þ)eMS/MS analysis of a lettuce sample fortified at a concentration of 50 ng g 1 d.w. are shown in Fig. 2. All target compounds were determined in the positive ionization mode in the same analytical run reducing analysis time and cost [34].
The reported methods are characterized by accurate quantification using internal standards, isotopically labelled internal standard and/or even isotopic dilution [26,31,32,40]. Isotopeswere used to account for efficiency (loss of analytes during sample preparation and matrix effects) [4,36,39]; however, isotopes were unavailable or too expensive for some analytes. In those cases, analyte spiked matrices were extracted and run throughout the analysis and compared with the analytical standards in a clean matrix to determine the extent of ion suppression or enhancement [32]. Otherwise, the peak area of each target compound is normalized with the peak area of the internal standard [29]. In difficult cases, such as, when detectors that lack enough selectivity are applied, standard addition method is used [40].
Until now, the number of wastewater-derived contaminants for which plant uptake has been studied is still limited. One of the remaining challenges within the field is the development of multiresidue methods able to cover as many emerging contaminants as possible and belonging to different types. Several methods have already been developed aimed to study the uptake of a larger number of micro-pollutants and possible metabolites. The latter are also included because studies have shown that contaminants can be transformed by the plant's metabolism. These studies which mostly focus on pharmaceuticals and commonly cover several tens of compounds [25,29,32e34,43,49] may serve as a starting point for further development of more comprehensive multiresidue methods. Sabourin et al. [28] have already presented an outstanding studywhich reportsmethod to analyse simultaneously
118 pharmaceuticals and transformation products, 17 hormones or hormone transformation products, and 6 parabens in biosolids and crop samples following their harvest. Separation and determination of the analytes was carried out according to the United State Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) method 1694 that uses LCeMS/MS in both positive and negative mode. LODs ranged from 0.12 to 1403 ng g 1 dry weight. To improve hormone identity confirmation, a GCeMS method based on the original EPA method 1698 was used. Eight of the 141 analytes were detected in one or two crop replicates at concentrations ranging from 0.33 to 6.25 ng g 1 dry weight.
The possible metabolism of these emerging contaminants in plants is the other hot topic within this field because of the need to enlarge the list of identified metabolites that may differ from those in humans. High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) has become the technique of choice since it provides the full MS scan, gives information on the empirical data and also provides MS/MS full scans on the product ions. Only one study qualitatively assesses the presence of ibuprofen and its transformation products in duckweed (Lemma gibba) plants by UHPLC-Q-Orbitap detecting 11 metabolic products in plant extracts. This paper reports the first evidence of ibuprofen absorption and its possible metabolism in duckweed, demonstrating that, in addition to ibuprofen, ibuprofen metabolites are also detectable in plants and in the growth medium. Furthermore, they throw light on the metabolic pathways characteristic of plants [10]. More studies on the metabolism of an increasing number of emerging contaminants in different types of plants are expected in the near future.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Gas chromatography
sections.text:
GC is less often used than LC to separate emerging contaminants because the majority of the studies focus on the determination of very polar contaminants as pharmaceuticals and PCPs. Polar compounds can be derivatized to be transformed in GC-amenable compounds but these procedures can cause a variety of practical problems that limit their application [28].
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189 179
GC remains the primary technique for non-polar compounds, which have mainly been separated on non-polar stationary phases, mostly 5% phenyl methyl-polysiloxane, such as HP5, DB-5ms, TR5ms, Ultra-2, CPSil-8 and SE-54 [39]. The column lengths vary from 15 m up to 30 m; most common are columns of 30 m 0.25 mm of internal diameter and 0.25 mm of film thickness. Although ECD and mECD have been sporadically reported to determine PBDEs and pesticides, GCeMS is the routine technique for most of these
applications (Table 1). Electron impact ionization (EI) and negative chemical ionization (NCI) have been applied in MS. The latter mostly for PBDEs because the MS-NCI combination has proven to be highly sensitive, especially for compounds with more than four bromine atoms; the sensitivity of NCI for these compounds is approximately 10-fold higher than that obtained with EI [25]. The LODs range from tens to hundreds of pg. The most applied mass analyser is the single quadrupole applied in the selected ion
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189180
monitoring (SIM) mode in order to achieve LODs as low as possible although part of the structural information of the detected analytes is then lost. The single-quadrupole analyzers are widely used but show limitations in analyzing complex mixtures of compounds because they fail to identify large numbers of compounds, especially when they are structurally related.
This lack of specificity has been solved using HReMS. With this technique, the sensitive full-spectrum acquisition is complemented with mass accuracy that provides an extraordinary potential for
qualitative purposes. GCeHRMS has been applied to determine PBDEs because in the case of biotic samples, the high sensitivity in the full-spectrum-acquisition mode of HRMS compared to conventional scanning instruments was needed in order to ensure appropriate identification of the PBDEs congeners [25]. To our best knowledge, this is the only relevant study using HRMS in the present field.
It seems difficult to analyse pharmaceuticals, hormones and PCPs without derivatization, because of their high polarity and low
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189 181
volatility [26,46]. Derivatizing these emerging contaminants into more volatile derivatives is compulsory to enhance detection sensitivity and to improve separation, especially for samples containing trace levels. Sabourin et al. [28] determined several hormones following the US EPAmethod 1698modified to include extra labelled internal standards and additional target analytes. Extracts were derivatized with N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (BSTFA) prior to analysis by GC and low resolution MS (LRMS) or HRMS [28]. Most of the hormones were also analysed by LCeMS/ MS. Better LODs were achieved for most analytes using the LCeMS/ MS method, with the exception of androsterone and estriol. Furthermore, derivatization requires a complicated, tedious procedure, resulting in a number of drawbacks (e.g., losses and unexpected oxidation of some compounds, less stability of derivatives than original compounds, and incomplete derivatization and extraction).

sections.heading: 3. Nanomaterials
sections.text:
According to their chemical composition, nanomaterials are classified as metal-based, carbon-based, organics and composites [55,56]. To date, a series of studies that characterize ENMs in plant tissues by different analytical techniques have been published (Table 2). Only metal-based and carbon-based materials have been determined [57,58]. The analytical characterization of the former is more advanced than that of the latter, probably metallic and metal oxide NPs are the most widely used ENMs. A workflow to characterize and quantify ENMs in plant tissues is presented in Fig. 3. The determination of particle size, concentration, aggregation, and chemical stability in plant tissues is of critical importance to the understanding of their impacts, ENMs can be considered as a newtype of analyte. In response to this challenge many analytical methods have been adapted, improved or developed.
Many studies on ENMs in plants involve laboratory and conditions-controlled experiments to establish uptake, distribution and translocation in plant tissues [57,59e70], long term stability, bioavailability and degradation [71e73] and effects such as biochemical response, toxic effects and nutritional quality on the plant [15e17,74e76]. ENMs would impact differently plant specific functions depending on their location (at tissue and cellular level), agglomeration state, and/or chemistry; techniques that offer both spatial and chemical information are highly appreciated. This section has been divided into three subsections. The first covers microscopic techniques that visualize any type of ENMs, the second describes methods to determine only metallic NPs (mostly spectroscopic techniques) and the third the few methods already described to determine carbon based ENMs.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microscopic techniques
sections.text:
Visualization of ENMs in plant tissues requires preservation of tissue structure and integrity of the components in the imaging environment (e.g. high or low vacuum). Sample preparation includes any type of fixation, dehydration and embedding tissue in resins [81] that can be carried out by chemical or cryo-methods. For more in-depth information, Dudkiewicz et al. [82] published an overview of approaches used for sample preparation for determining ENMs by microscopy. These procedures ranged from the traditional one: dehydration with glutaraldehyde, fixation with osmium tetroxide and embedding in epoxy resin to immerse the sample in a droplet of resin (Tissue Teck Sakura) and immediately cryo-fixed by plunging the sample in isopentane cooled with liquid nitrogen. Most of the studies established that cryofixation is more appropriate for biological specimens.
Electron microscopy is a recognized standard tool for ENM size measurement and location in plant materials. Most studies involved the use of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) or scanning electron microscopy (SEM) including variations as scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) [59,60,66,74], but also optical microscopy techniques, such as confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) [67] to localize ENMs as well as establish particle size, and size distribution. The use of microscopy visualizes the ENMs in the plan tissue providing information on size but not on chemical composition. Furthermore, TEM is a powerful technique to characterize pure synthesized NPs; however, its applications to environmental and biological samples are limited by its sensitivity because with this technology it is difficult to detect the environmentally relevant concentrations of NPs. A good example is provided by Dan et al. [59] who were not able to confirm by TEM the presence of CeO2NPs in plant shoots. However, these particles were detected by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPeMS). These results might indicate the absence of CeO2NPs in the selected sample or CeO2NPs present, but the concentrationwas too low to be detected by TEM. Other studies have encountered similar sensitivity problem to detect several types of NPs. Furthermore, the visualization of metal based ENMs is quite wellestablished but not that of carbon-based materials that have more interferences. The combination of TEM or SEM to energydispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) adds information on the elemental composition or chemical characterization of the ENM even inside the plant tissue [62,75]. Gogos et al. [62] who studied plant uptake and the vertical translocation of three different TiO2 NPs and MWCNTs in a pot experiment provided an illustrative example of the information contributed by these techniques (Fig. 4). However, the same study showed that the use of TEM imaging on cross sections of the plant roots was not conclusive to confirm uptake of MWCNTs [62]. Although the protocols for sample preparation are well established, and this is the technique of reference to establish the presence of ENMs, the technique can pose problem that are not resolved yet.

sections.heading: 3.2. Other determination and characterization techniques for metal-based NPs
sections.text:
Most of the analytical methods for studying metals and elements are now being challenged by nanotechnology. Inorganic ENMs can be released from plant materials by wet digestion with a strong acid (nitric, perchloric, hydrogen peroxide etc …), even using microwave assisted digestion (MAD). This approach has been widely used to determine concentrations of different metal oxides e TiO2, CeO2, ZnO, SiO2, Ag and gold. The metals are commonly determined by inductively coupled plasma with optical emission spectrometry (ICPeOES), ICPeMS or total reflection X-ray fluorescence (TXRF). Total metal content can be determined but neither nanoform nor spatial distribution can be established [61]. However, its combination, for example, with TEM or SEM provides information on the chemical composition of the visualized ENMs [60,62,66,74].
There are some examples, in which the ENMs are measured by specific properties, for example in the case of Fe3O4 that has magnetic properties. Their measurement in a wide range of temperature or magnetic fields (parameter on which magnetization depends) allows to construct a curve to estimate the number of NPs. The distribution of these particles was tracked by magnetization in Arabidopsis thaliana and common beans [68,75].
Beam-based techniques permit to have access to localized information. Electron spectroscopies [X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), particleinduced X-ray emission (PIXE) and Rutherford backscattering

spectroscopy (RBS) including the micro-version of the techniques] provide information about topography, elemental composition, molecular and chemical state, structure and quantity [72,76,79]. For example, XANES can detect metal speciation inside plant tissues and detect several effects associated with the nanocrystalline nature of materials [76]. Samples of plant tissueswere prepared under cryogenic conditions as previously described for electron microscopy. Larue et al. [78] present the use of cutting-edge beam-based techniques for TiO2 and Ag NPs in situ localization, quantification and speciation in a crop plant species (Lactuca sativa). Mapping of low-Z elements (H, C, N and O) was performed using RBS, in parallel with PIXE for the quantification of elements heavier than Mg. The LOD is around 100 mg g 1. Metal speciation in situ was determined by mXANES after mapped elemental distribution and synchrotron radiation based-mXRF. The LOD of mXRF is lower than for mPIXE, i.e. around 1 mg g 1 in the tissues. The limit to assure a good XANES data quality is one or two orders of magnitude higher.
Another approach is a laser-based technique, viz. laser ablation inductively coupled mass spectrometry (LAeICPeMS), a powerful analytical technology that enables highly sensitive elemental and isotopic analysis directly on solid samples. The sample preparation merely requires drying the samples, mounting them on a 3 M mounting tape, and fixing each sample on a petrographic slide (similar to the methods used in microscopy). Therefore, LAeICPeMSmay offer unique capabilities to investigate the uptake and distribution of ENMs within plant tissues. This technique has been applied to establish the uptake and spatial distribution of engineered AuNPs with different surface charges in rice roots and shoots providing successful results [65]. Sample size and preparation are minimal for LAeICPeMS, minimizing nitric acid waste compared to bulk analysis but the limitation of LCeICPeMS is the lack of suitable matrix-matched solid analyte standards at an appropriate calibration range. In this study, this was solved with much ingenuity by preparing a suite of in house standards for quantitative determination of Au distribution. The LOD is about mg L 1. The most important disadvantage is that in LAeICPeMS, the
ablated material is transferred into the ICP through tubing by a carrier gas. This process has many technical difficulties.
Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) can provide information not only about the bulk elemental composition of a solid sample but also about the spatial distribution of elements of interest on the surface of the solid sample. LIBS can be successfully used for 2D elemental mapping of samples. The spatial resolution of 50 mm of the method enables a reliable differentiation of the contents of elements in three distinct anatomical layers of the roots, namely root surface with the rhizodermis, cortex, and central cylinder, and was adequate for the size of the cells in the analysed tissues.
Another promising technique is single particle inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (SPeICPeMS) which can provide information about the NP number concentration, mass concentration, size and number size distribution of NP suspensions as well as about the presence of the particulate and/or dissolved form in complex samples at environmentally relevant concentrations. The sample is digested using special macerating enzymes (Macerozyme R-10) that release the ENMs from plant tissues without changing the size distributions. This method has been tested for CeO2-NPs [59] and Ag-NPs [60] showing excellent results in further nanoform characterization. In SPeICPeMS, a single NP entering the plasma is vaporized producing a cloud of gaseous ions, which is detected as a single pulse, whereas the corresponding dissolved analyte is measured as a steady signal. Therefore, SPeICPeMS is able to distinguish between the dissolved analyte (continuous signal) and the analyte in NP form (pulses above the continuous background). The frequency of the pulses can be correlated with the particle number concentration and the intensity of each pulse is proportional to the mass of the nanoparticle. Applications to plants are still limited to the characterization of Ag-NPs in tomato, platinum NPs in aquatic plants and CeO2-NPs in cucumber, tomato, soybean and pumpkins [59,60,64]. Fig. 5 shows the raw data of SPeICPeMS for four types of plants. Subpanel labels a, c, e, and g of Fig. 5 show the raw data of control plants for tomato, cucumber,
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189 185
pumpkin, and soybean, respectively. Subpanels b, d, f, and h of Fig. 5 display the raw data for tomato, cucumber, pumpkin, and soybean dosed with 7 mg L 1 of 30e50 nm CeO2NPs for 19 days, respectively. It is clear from the SPeICPeMS outputs that there was uptake of Ce from the dosing solutions. The presence of both types of signals (continuous and pulses) indicates that both dissolved and particulate Ce were present in plant tissues. However, the exact chemical composition of these particulate Ce was not determined because the ICPeMS just detected 140Ce (most stable isotope free of interference). Some pulse signals were also identified in the control (Subpanels a, c, e and g). The presence of these pulse signals could explained by the adsorption of Ce ions onto the surface of undigested plant tissue colloids that would be recognized as particles. Particle size LODs depend on the type of NPs; reported values are about 20 nm. Although SPeICPeMS techniques have very low LODs (down to ng kg 1), and provide essential information, they cannot provide spatial information. Furthermore, improved particle size LODs are needed.

sections.heading: 3.3. Other determination and characterization techniques for carbon-based ENMs
sections.text:
Carbon-based ENMs are more difficult to characterize and determine; therefore many studies used specifically labelled particles for easier detection [73,80]. They provide interesting information but are not realistic or relevant from an applicationdirected point of view.
The sample treatment to quantify carbon-based materials has only been described for multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) that are further determined by microwave induced heating (MIH). The sample treatment is one of the most simplest, dry, grind and powder [62,69]. Carbon NPs can be difficult to detect in the plant tissues and more research is needed. However, recently, some pioneering studies report the use of MIH for the quantification of MWCNTs. These ENMs have a high microwave absorption capacity, which results in a rapid rise in temperature within a very short microwave exposure time [62,69]. The proper application of the
Y. Pic o et al. / Trends in Analytical Chemistry 94 (2017) 173e189 187
method requires the generation of a calibration curve using the thermal response as a function of known CNTs spiked into selected plant materials [62]. This technique has already successfully been applied to a wide variety of plant tissues, including barley, corn, wheat, rice, soybean, switchgrass, tomato and red clover [62,69].
Furthermore, fluorescent carbon dots (CDs) have been widely studied in bioscience and bioimaging because of their optical properties that also allows to visualize them by confocal imaging inside the plant [57], a simple system to understand the uptake and translocation of CDs by optical analysis in vivo. This system was applied to study the phytotoxicity, uptake, and translocation of red emissive CDs in plants.
Obviously a number of strategies and applications have already been described for a MWCNTs and carbon dots. For other types of carbon-based ENMs, however, similar analytical approaches are not feasible because of their variable lengths and structures. Quantification at trace levels in complex samples has not been solved yet. Then, continued method development and instrumentation advances are still desired.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and trends
sections.text:
Sample treatment to determine emerging contaminants in plant materials involves exhaustive SLE aided by microwaves, ultrasound or high pressures and/or temperatures and SPE clean-up. At the present, LCeMS/MS or GCeMS are the most widely used techniques for determination. Method development should focus on exploiting all features to enhance sensitivity and to obtain accurate quantification. In other words, the development of rapid analyses covering a wide range of emerging contaminants and their transformation products and/or plant metabolites should get priority. HRMS presents an exciting opportunity to address the significant challenges associated with the transformation and metabolism of emerging contaminants in the plant. One promising application already reported the identification of more than 11 transformation products of ibuprofen in plants [9]. However, there are only few real-life studies yet, and metabolite detection is in its infancy. Progress in this area over the next few years can be expected to lead to important information on the metabolism of an increasing number of emerging contaminants in different types of plant.
Methods for the screening of ENMs in plants reveal technological developments of major importance for their detection, characterization and quantification. Combining ENM visualization in the different parts of the plant with chemical analysis and quantification is becoming more robust. New developments in instrumentation and methods for the visualization, characterization and quantification of the ENMs should further advance the goal of developing truly low-cost, high sensitivity analysis suitable for a wide range of metal ENMs. The recent methods to quantify carbonbased ENMs are a good example of the prospects within this field. However, much more research is still needed, because these techniques are at present restricted to MWCNTs and other carbonbased nanomaterials with special optical properties.

metadata.abstractText: The reuse of treated wastewater or wastewater-impacted river water is growing, particularly in arid areas, due to the climate change. As well, the disposal of sludges, biosolids or biochar as soil amendments to improve agricultural output is widely implemented in the EU. These practices can be a source of emerging contaminants and engineering nanomaterials (ENMs) to the environment and condition their incorporation to food chain that could affect human beings. This review covers current analytical techniques, instruments and methodologies used to determine emerging contaminants and ENMs from irrigation water and/or soil amendments in plants. Trends regarding sample treatment, separation and detection approaches are addressed. Special emphasis is placed on in-situ characterization of ENMs (e.g. particle size distribution, shape, aggregation state, etc.). We also discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the analytical methods and techniques for determining emerging contaminants and fully ENMs characterization, and cover promising future prospects. © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
